In pursuance of the Conclusion referredto in the margin, the Cabinet met to hear the".,,,reports on the meetings which had taken placeearlier in the day, including the meeting between certain Cabinet Ministers and the Leadersof the Opposition Parties. At the outset a communication from the General Council of theTrade Union Congress was read intimating that theCouncil had appointed a Committee to place theviews of the Council before the Cabinet.It was agreed That the Cabinet Committee on theReport of the Committee on national expenditure should meet the Committeeof the General Council that same evening at 9.JO P.m., and should report the views of the Council tothe Cabinet at the meeting at 10.0 a.m.on Friday, August 21st, 1931.The Cabinet were informed by the Chancellorof the Exchequer that the Prime Minister and himself had that morning met Mr. neville chamberlain, Sir S. Hoare, Sir H. Samuel and SirDonald Maclean and had outlined the economyproposals. The meeting had been cordial, but theConservative Leaders had expressed doubts as to the feasibility of securing the contemplated cutsin the estimates of the Fighting Services andhad intimated quite definitely that in their view the proposed savings on unemployment insurancewould fail to satisfy expectations, and that,unless substantial^ larger economies on this service were realised, the whole scheme wouldbe rendered ineffective. No reference hadbeen made by the Conservative Leaders to thequestion of a Revenue Tariff. As regards the revenue proposals all the Opposition Leadershad made it clear that they could not possibly contemplate the imposition of newtaxation of the order of 100 million, andhad urged the need for securing a much largeraggregate economy figure, if public confidencewas to be restored.The Prime Minister added that he had seen Mr. Neville Chamberlain again later inthe day. Mr. Chamberlain had expressed theopinion that, in view of the size of the prospective deficit, the object in view would not be attained unless economies of theorder of approximately 100 million in theaggregate were secured and in this connection he (lir. Chamberlain) had strongly advocatedmore drastic action as regards the unemploymentinsurance proposals.The President of the Board of Tradestated that subsequently he had seenSir EL, Samuel who was in a position toindicate the views of Mr. Lloyd George. the liberals also favoured more drastic actionIn regard to. unemployment insurance, and, iniparticular, urged reduction of benefits andother changes designed to secure substantial savings on that service. They suggested thetemporary suspension of the Sinking Fund andwere most strongly opposed to a Revenue Tariffanyin/shape or form. On an estimated expenditure in1932 of 143 millions on this Service, the recentefforts of the Government to secure savings had only resulted in reducing this great item of ex-penditure by about 5 per cent, or by about 5 percent, if the 3 millions of the recent A.ctwas disregarded.The situation to-day was that UnemploymentInsurance economies were put at 22 millions andother economies at 30 millions, or 52 millions in all, leaving a gap to be filled by taxation of 118 millions. This figure would of course, haveto be increased if, as seemed certain, it was found impossible to realise the 50 millions fromeconomies other than Unemployment Insurance. Inthis connection the Cabinet were reminded that thevalue of Unemployment benefit to-day was over 30per cent, higher than the 1924 value, and that thatvalue had been accepted as adequate by the thenLabour Government at a time when the Budgets were showing handsome surpluses. The present position,with its prospective enormous deficit and vastincrease of taxation, was contrasted with theposition in 1924 and emphasis was laid on thefact that while the wage earner was receiving the same value as in 1924, 0 9 9t? ki 4ithe real value of -unemployment "benefit had risen by over 30 per cent.
